title: Will Keiko Fujimori win Peru's upcoming presidential election?
preds: Count over 99.9% done and 42k vote difference remaining. That's all, folks!
Kuczynski’s lead is greater than total uncounted votes, per perureports.com

I was badly wrong on this one, had predicted 75% then upgraded to 90% then 95%, all in response to polls. Either polls were inaccurate (Ipsos had KF ahead of PPK by 1-2% even accounting for margins of error) or people really did change their mind less than a week before the election. Even if KF ends up winning, it was WAY closer than I had predicted or the polls had indicated.

With about 360k, or less as Gibson pointed out, disputed ballots sent to a "special electoral board" I think this is a blow for Kuczynski. This election has been described as  "semi-democractic" by media analysts. The electoral boards have shown several times to rule hard against her opponents but go easy on her. 
I get the impression too that the atmosphere in Peru is tense, and both candidates are taking pains to stay silent or promote "calm And tranquility". This makes me think Peruvians expect her votes to prevail. Ppk had a surprisingly strong showing for an underdog so I think the  outcome whatever it is might leave a lot of people unhappy.
Very few votes left to count, though some may be reviewed. She's behind by a very small margin, but she can only hope and pray now. Very unlikely.

In last Sunday's presidential debate, PPK was the clear winner. He focused on highlighting his experience and legacy as Finance Minister and Prime Minister, as well as the party that represents democracy. In contrast to the previous debate, he answered every dirty attack and lie that Keiko threw at him, while also making a link between drug trafficking, corruption (activities that were linked to Alberto Fujimori's government and that in recent weeks have been strongly associated with the current Fujimori party) and crime, which has become the main concern of people in Lima. He criticised Keiko for missing 500 days of work as a Congresswoman (she answered that she went on maternity leave twice, but that only covers 180 days), asked if she was going to extradit her uncles from Japan, who have ongoing corruption charges in Peru (she said that she was not going to interfere with justice), and wondered why the police had found over 100kg of cocaine in a warehouse owned by Kenji, Keiko's brother (she said that it was normal that drug trafficking infiltrate local businesses!?!?!?!?). He ended the debate on a high note. In Piura, Keiko told him "How have you changed, pelona" (in reference to a known poem), because he supported her last elections. In the last debate, PPK answered: "You haven't changed a little bit, pelona, you are still the same", in reference to her father's legacy and her role as first lady in his government. Moreover, Veronika Mendoza, the left-wing leader and third on the first round, decided to publicly support PPK for Sunday's election, which could prove as a vital boost in this last week. Lourdes Flores Nano, PPC's leader, has also shown support for PPK, while the party Accion Popular, fourth during the first round, also publicly supported PPK's campaing. This could prove as a last bit impulse to PPK's campaign, which could help revert the gap. No more polls will be published in the media this week. Nonetheless, they are still made and tend to leak in social media. So, I will post the results if I get them. Finally, today is the second Demonstration against Keiko in the Lima centre. Let's see how that goes.

See link below) The first debate between Keiko and PPK just wrapped up tonight and it's expected to help with the undecided voters. http://elcomercio.pe/politica/elecciones/asi-van-keiko-y-ppk-encuestas-antes-primer-debate-noticia-1903092?ref=nota_politica&ft=mod_leatambien&e=titulo It will be interesting to see how the first debate affects the polls. In my estimation, Keiko had the best performance in terms of "energy" but she came across as too rehearsed while PPK came across as the candidate with the most comprehensive policies, also the most judicious and trustworthy (from social media reactions).  Something that came up during the debate and that resonated quickly (on social media, at least) was PPL BEING LOW ENERGY AND BEING 77 YEAR OLD.  
PPK IS ALSO BEING ATTACKED FOR HAVING A US PASSPORT and for allegations that he would sell the country to foreigners. Apparently he made an 8 day trip to the US which he says wast to campaign with expatriots who will be voting overseas but Keiko is using that to feed foreign ties conspiracies.  This first debate was held in the north side of the country, Keiko's strong hold. The second debate will take place on May 29 and will be held in the south.   What else can we look at in such a close election?   Demographics:  
Peru's population is 31,745,778.  50.1% Males. 49.9% Females. 
Literacy rate for adult male population is 97.28% (10 717 148 persons). 299,770 are illiterate.
Literacy rate for adult female population is 91.7% (10 597 400 persons). 958,693 are illiterate.
Youth literacy rates are 98.89% and 98.99% for males and females accordingly.  https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pe.html
Amerindians are still 45% of the population.  
The south part of the country and rural areas were Umala's stronghold and went to Veronica Mendoza and PPK on the first round.  It's expected to remain the same.  Keiko's popularity is much higher in the coastal areas across the land (both in 2011 and on the 2016 first round).
I haven't found indication of voter preference along gender or age lines.  Ollanta Umala's popularity at end of his term: 
His government was tainted by corruption allegations involving his wife (he is exempt from indictment while in office).  He is credited with maintaining the same economic policy and relative economic stability but he has let a lot of people down as his investment in social programs or lifting people out of poverty was not what many expected.  The issue of Alberto Fujimori's corruption case and subsequent 25 year prison sentence and Keiko's ties to her father's government and legacy.  In 2011, Keiko famously said "vamos a sacar al chino de la carcel" or "we are going to get the Chinese man out of prison (referring to her dad).  During this campaign, she has said that there has been no evidence of the crimes her father was accused.  She has also said that she is running separate from her father.  Interestingly, Keiko has made alliances with, it appears, any faction that would have her. She famously made an alliance with independent miners who are said to be wrecking havoc on the environment. Her ties to known drug lords and money launderers have made headlines many times this year. But she has been very successful in  separating herself, as the most able candidate with a strong populist appeal.  She is adept as using soundbytes and simple language that gets to the people.  In 2011, UMALA received 51.45% of the vote and Keiko received 48.55%.  UMALA was a lot more charismatic than PPK is and Keiko has had time to mature and learn more about the process. In the past few weeks I think we have learned some important lessons about forecasting elections. In the USA, pundits and analysts (even credible ones like Nate Silver) predicted for months that Trump would not be the Republican nominee. They told all kinds of stories and had all kinds of logical arguments for this claim. But they ignored or underestimated the importance of the polls, and guess what, the polls were right. Recently I was forecasting (and therefore following) the Philippine election [1]. Early on, there were all kinds of stories and logical arguments on why Rodrigo Duterte would not win the election. He is basically a crazy, confessedly murderous, justice-ignoring, vigilante-supporting, Trump on steroids, who while running made frequent remarks about his use of Viagra, his having three girlfriends, and joked about the rape of an Australian nun. Now, the Philippines are a very Christian country --- e.g. they banned Blizzard's hit game Diablo 3 [2] and almost banned Diablo 2 more than a decade ago. They make it very hard for basic sex ed to be taught and for people to have access to birth control. (I have a friend there who works in this branch of public health and she struggles.) Any story or logical argument you can come up with is going to say that Duterte would NEVER get elected. Christianity is against murder and polygamy and rape of nuns right? Except the polls told a different story, and the polls were right again. I for one was too slow to react to them. Last week Duterte was elected with 39% of the vote. (Not sure why the GJO question is still pending resolution.) All this is to say that investigations of this or that person, this or that government scandal, or even the fact that Fujimori's dad was a murderous dictator --- these are, I think, poor predictors. We need to look at the polls, especially since we are very close to the election. The average of the last 3 polls conducted by Ipsos (Peru's foremost polling organization as far as I can tell) have Fujimori at 43.7% and Kuczynski at 40.9%, with Fujimori ahead in every single one [3,4,5]. This is further strengthened by an Ipsos poll where voters were divided according to educational level [6]: Fujimori has a massive, 10-20% lead among those with less than a college degree, which is almost everyone in Peru. I had trouble finding the percentage of college graduates in Peru, but one source [7] claims Peru currently has 78 universities serving 500k students. Assuming each student stays in college 4 years and generously assuming the current situation stretches back 20 years, we find 2.5M college graduates (probably much less) among a voting-age population of 21M [8] (voting is compulsory in Peru). The average number of years of schooling for a Peruvian adult is just 7.6 years --- less than high school, the level at which Fujimori's support is greatest. In view of all this I am revising my 75% forecast substantially up. Let's generously assume Kuczynski is actually ahead in voting intentions but it's very close, so that on any given poll he has a 50% chance of coming out ahead. What, then, are the odds that Fujimori would come out ahead in 3 polls? Just 12.5%. The odds are even worse if Kuczynski was substantially ahead in voting intentions. So I'm calling a 10% chance that the latest polls don't reflect reality. Thus, Fujimori 90% to win. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/144-who-will-win-the-upcoming-philippine-presidential-election
[2] https://sowhatsnews.wordpress.com/2012/05/17/retailers-ordered-to-stop-selling-diablo-3-after-cbcp-was-granted-tro-by-sc/
[3] http://rpp.pe/politica/elecciones/keiko-fujimori-le-saca-3-puntos-de-ventaja-a-ppk-en-nueva-encuesta-de-ipsos-noticia-960377
[4] http://rpp.pe/politica/elecciones/cpi-keiko-fujimori-obtiene-458-y-pedro-pablo-kuczynski-40-noticia-961884
[5] http://rpp.pe/politica/elecciones/encuesta-de-ipsos-da-un-empate-tecnico-entre-ppk-y-keiko-fujimori-noticia-962330

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-election-idUSKCN0XP05H A spat between presidential contender Keiko Fujimori and her younger brother over the future leadership of the political movement they inherited from their ex-president father could cost her key votes in Peru's tight June 5 run-off election.  .  . . Keiko threatened to throw Kenji Fujimori out of her political party after he stoked fears that the family harbors dynastic intentions by saying he will run for president in the next elections in 2021 if she loses this year, . . . [vowing] that no one with the Fujimori surname would seek the presidency in 2021 before her brother declared on Twitter: "the decision is mine." Critics said the dispute has laid bare a rift at the heart of their center-right party, Fuerza Popular, as patriarch Alberto Fujimori languishes in prison for corruption and human rights abuses committed during his 1990-2000 government. "Fujimori and her brother are fighting about who will get the piñata in 2021!" Fujimori's rival Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, a centrist economist, told reporters. "Peru is not a piñata." Kenji Fujimori, a 35-year-old lawmaker, has defended Alberto Fujimori more stridently than his sister and is widely seen as leading his father's hardline loyalists. Keiko Fujimori has striven to distance herself from her father's authoritarian rule and seized on her brother's defiance to shore up her democratic credentials. "Fuerza Popular rejects any attempt to alter the processes of internal party elections with a self-proclaimed candidacy 5 years before an election," Fujimori said. But the damage may have already been done, especially among middle-ground voters wary of the family's dominance, said Alfredo Torres, the director of pollster Ipsos in Peru. "I think Keiko reacted very well, she put Kenji in his place...but the balance is negative," said Torres. "It's going to be harder for her to win over undecided voters." Fujimori and Kuczynski have been virtually tied in recent opinion polls. She was seen winning 39 percent of votes to Kuczynski's 43 percent in an Ipsos survey published Sunday, with 18 percent of uncommitted voters still up for grabs. Keiko Fujimori is popular in rural districts where her father is celebrated for building schools and cracking down on guerrillas, but she faces stiff opposition from those who consider him a corrupt dictator. Kuczynski . . .  has scant support among poorer voters or in areas outside the capital Lima.

Her runoff is now against Kuczynski (K) (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-election-idUSKCN0X708N) after the candidates won 39.5% and 21.6% of the vote, respectively. Their pre-election polling had them at 33% and 16% (http://www.ipsos.pe/sites/default/files/opinion_data/OpinionData030416.pdf), meaning Fujimori (F) took home an extra 6% and K an extra 5% from the undecided. That same poll put them head-to-head, with a narrow 43-41 lead for F. If the undecideds in the runoff split as they did in the first election, F would receive an additional 9 points and K an additional 7, leading to a 52-48 split. Still very close, within the poll's MOE of 2.3%, meaning it's within 2 standard deviations. I'm leaning more towards the 50-50 side because my assumption that the undecideds split similarly is strong. 68% is 1SD, 95% is 2SD, so let's say 70% chance that F pulls it out in the runoff.

First, I googled who won Peru's past elections. Recent history: 1962 -- 1963 dictatorship
1963 -- 1968 democracy, 1 election
1968 -- 1980 dictatorship
1980 -- 2016 democracy, 8 elections I ignore the period before the first dictatorship because it seems too far in the past. Of these 9 elections, 6 have been won by the more right-wing party. I will say the base rate is 67% for the more right-wing candidate. Apparently the two current candidates, Fujimori the daugher and Kuczynski, are right-wing and center-right respectively, so I'll start with a 67% chance of Fujimori winning. One major concern in elections is that incumbents have the advantage. But thanks to Peruvian law, the incumbent cannot run. As far as I can tell the incumbent party doesn't support either candidate. In fact, past election results are in favor of Fujimori here: Kuczynski ran against her in the 2011 elections and came in behind her (18% to her 23% in the first round). Another big concern in these elections is that Fujimori's father is a known criminal and human rights abuser (sentenced do 25 years in prison in 2009); but apparently this didn't stop people liking Fujimori the daughter better than Kuczynski in 2011. All this makes me adjust the probability of her winning substantially up, to 80%. I dunno, I can't recall a time when A had more votes than B in one election, and then that reversed in the next election. Another big concern in any election is the economy. It is well-known that when the economy is bad people get voted out of office, even if it's not their fault. But again neither candidate is an obvious continuation of the current left-wing government so I won't make any change to the 80% odds. Finally, current data [1]. The first-round election had Fujimori with 40% and Kuczynski with 21%. Polls for the second round put Kuczynski at 43%, Fujimori at 41%, and 16% undecided. This is a strange reversal but I think I can explain it by votes to more left-wing candidates going to Kuczynski (they decide early). The 16% undecided is a lot and I think more likely to be distributed randomly, and therefore expected to follow previous trends. Still, the slight advantage of Kuczynski, and the fact that all other candidates were more left-wing than the two, makes me revise Fujimori's chances down to 75%. So: Fujimori 75% to win. [1] http://perureports.com/2016-elections-peru/

Simply put, she has a much shorter hill to climb than either of the two other candidates she might face in the upcoming run-off election. The two other candiates, Mendoza and Kuczynski have enough of a divergence in their bases that it would likely be difficult to mount an effective combination of forces to counter Fujimori. Much more likely that the Kuczynski centrists will find much more common ground with the Fuerza Popular. Despite the troubles of her father, which is a legacy she seems content to move beyond, it must be remembered that he was central to providing the needed improvements in infrastructure that allowed many Peruvians to extricate themselves from poverty, and his diminution of the threat of the Sendero Luminoso still remains an important factor in the minds of the Peruvian electorate. Therefore, it may appear in the electoral calculus of the voters that Keiko would likely commit herself to carry on the more acceptable policies of her father while pledging to maintain democracy as the choice of government. Lastly, let us remember that she almost defeated Humala in the elections of 2011 despite her father's damaging legacy.

The protests grab headlines, but the polls grab my attention. Even if a lot of people hate Keiko, a lot more people seem to like her. And the Panama Papers stuff seems to touch most of the other candidates as well -- I don't know why it would disadvantage her especially.

In my opinion, there are a couple of factors in play that point in different directions:
1) Economic disparity, Peru seemed on the verge of economic success in 2010/2011, but that has failed to materialize.  Couple that with an increase in economic disparity between rural and less affluent citizen vs urban / affluent citizens and everything points left.  This would make sense, but a) Peru, especially rural and young Peru, leans toward big changes and are distrustful of the political system http://www.vanderbilt.edu/lapop/peru/2010-political-culture.pdf + the current leftist leader is very unpopular and distrusted.  This suggests that even though voters  may support leftist ideologies, they would not expect the leftist candidate Mendoza (who is of the same party as the current president) to be the answer.  She is sitting around 15-20% in most polls and that seems about right. 2)The other non Fujimori candidate, Kucynski, is pretty much tied with Mendoza in the polls.  At the same time, he is not a political insider (+) and has seen a steady increase in popularity in the past month (I know, momentum isn't really a thing in politics but still a soft +).  He has economic bonafides that the other 2 candidates don't (very soft +) and doesn't have any baggage (strong +, but I maybe overstating it).  At the same time, he will struggle with rural voters and does not  properly appeal to leftists (the left leaning party has the largest portion of the Peruvian legislature).  I have questions about his ability to mobilize the vote and if he can beat Fujimori for right-leaning voters. 3)Fujimori has lost before, few candidates in any country can bounce back from a loss (to be fair it was a close loss, so this may not be as large of a factor).  My concerns with her are voter fatigue both with her and her disgraced father.  The Peruvian people may be sick of the Fujimoris.  There is the whole corruption thing, but that hasn't really hurt her so far.  Peru seems to be leaning to the left right now, but only slightly.  The election is still her's to lose, but I think her advantage is very very small, and I have a hard time seeing her getting the 50% necessary to win the general.  The protests also hurt her.

This election is going to be heavily contested due to recent developments concerning the front runner and her most competitive opponent. In the past three presidential election in Peru the runner up has had a substantial advantage in following presidential election due to a perceived incumbency advantage.   The front runner, Keiko Fujimori has that advantage and it's been reflected in the polls with her almost always leading by a 10-15% margin over her opponents in the first round of voting. However she still doesn't posses the needed 50% to skip the runoff vote. Fujimori's luck turned however when the Peruvian National Election Board ruled that Guzman had not filed the proper paper work that would have official established his party and his candidacy putting his campaign on suspension with little hope of a successful appeal. Fujimori has only one other competitor that gets even within striking distance of her runoff polling numbers; that person being Pedro Pablo Kuczynshi.  An economist who's served time as the prime minister, as well as the minister of finance and of mining and energy during previous administrations, Kuczynski finished in third in the last election and has been polled 39% to Fujimori's 44%. While this margin is larger than that Guzman had before his suspension; the recent release of the Panama papers (which contained Fujimori's name) could embolden Kucynski's economic platform if he focused on tax and corruption reform at the expense of Fujimori's political standing. COMMENT:  I do not know what the laws regarding separation of church and state are in Peru, but as a Roman Catholic, I consider it totally inappropriate and extremely unwise for anyone in a leadership position (including the Pope) in any church to give an opinion about a candidate.   In this situation, we have a bishop emeritus disagreeing with an archbishop.  The archbishop is the higher authority, but statements on this kind of issue are weighed by the faithful based on their perception of the men making them.  The words of a long-time beloved and respected bishop emeritus would out-weigh the words of an archbishop who is perceived as a light-weight or new-comer.  I cannot comment on the relative weight these 2 men have with the Peruvian faithful.

So there's a lot of conflicting stuff here, but lets try to sort through the facts one at a time.   http://www.as-coa.org/articles/explainer-whos-running-2016-peruvian-presidential-election There's a lot of data here, but the point about her being a woman, as well as the daughter of an ex-president, and being tough on crime are all crucial indicators of current political status.  She is currently polling very strong (about 30% where none of the other candidates breach 20%).  It seems really clear that nobody is going to get more than a plurality in the first round of elections, putting this almost entirely down to the second round.  The consensus does seem to be that a second round will be between PPK and Fujimori, so it seems safe to argue it with the implicit assumption that will happen.  If somehow PPK does not have an opportunity to run in the 2nd round, this question gets a lot simpler.  Guzman's eviction from the race will probably push a lot of supporters to PPK's side as well.  This all looks pretty good for Fujimori, but... http://www.peruviantimes.com/28/vargas-llosa-calls-keiko-fujimoris-lead-for-president-troubling/26280/ "Ipsos poll showed that Kuczynski would defeat Fujimori in a second round vote, with 42 percent versus 38 percent support, respectively" - This is really the most damning thing for Fujimori, as is evidenced by the massive riots against her (49% -> http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Peruvians-Protest-Keiko-Fujimori-and-Electoral-Dirty-War-20160324-0032.html) which must have something to do with her fathers crimes. To me, the big enigmas here are will PPK be able to organize the anti-Fujimori populace under his leadership, and, on a related note, how many voters will simply lose interest between the first and second elections if their candidate does not win. Overall, I'd rate her odds as fairly good.  She has a lot of strong backing, and her policies of modernization seem to speak to a lot of Peruvians.  However, the threats to her candidacy are too real to be dismissed.

Veronika Mendoza and Alfredo Barnechea On Easter, in front of the assembled worshippers, the Archbishop of Peru's 2nd largest city told Catholics that it would be a sin if they voted for Veronika Mendoza or Alfredo Barnechea,  who have been tied for 3rd place in the polls, because of their positions on abortion and gay rights.  The Archbishop didn't also condemn Kuczynski (who supports civil unions) and Fujimori (who also is in favor of expanded civil rights for gays), perhaps because they oppose abortion unless the mother's life is in jeopardy.  The Archbishop's words will sway many votes, making it more likely that Fujimori & Kuczynski will the top 2 candidates in the run-off election.

Starting low on Fujimori's chances.   Fuerza Popular (FP): Keiko Fujimori's party took 23% of the 1st round vote in 2011 and gained another 24.9% in the 2nd round, running against Ollanta Humala's left wing coalition (it moved to the center in the 2nd round, and allied with Peru Posible, a centrist party that had 16% of the 1st round vote). It also seems very likely that most of the Fujimori's gain in the 2nd round came from centrist parties, in effect splitting the centrists vote. That may not happen this election.  Currently Fujimori has fallen from 33% to 30% in the latest polls.  Strong on the current issue of crime reduction, yet her father remains an obstacle with some of the electorate.  And if the centrists can consolidate, FP may be boxed into a right wing corner. Failure of the centrist parties to settle on a single candidate in 2011 resulted in an election between a right wing party and a center left party.  Peru has around 25 parties contesting this year's election, even though many of the candidates are from parties that are from larger alliances.  For example, The National Solidarity Alliance, led by Luis Castaneda's National Alliance Party, also includes, among others Cambio90 (led by Renzo Reggiardo-who has left the Presidential race), Siempre Unidos (led by Felipe Castillo - has also left the race), and Todos por el Peru (led by Julio Guzman- who was just barred from running). Another case is the centrist "Alliance for Great Change" led by Luis Castaneda, also contained the "Alliance for Progress" led by the now barred Cesar Acuna.  
------> Barring Guzman and Acuna, seem to allow the centrist parties to consolidate around three leaders (see below).  As long as one of the 3 centrist parties finishes 2nd in the 1st round of the election, Fujimora will have no significant voter block to gain in the second round.  Currently it does not seem likely that either Garcia's left center Popular Alliance, or Mondoza's left front will make the second round. Center and center right parties:
..."Alliance for Great Change" (Pedro Pablo Kuczynski), composed of:
............Alliance for Progress (Cesar Acuna) - barred
............Humanist Party (Yehude Simon) <5%
............National Restoration Party
............Popular Christian Party (Antero Flores Araoz) <5% ..National Solidarity Alliance (Luis Castaneda), composed of:
............National Solidarity Party (Renzo Reggiardi) - out of race
............Cambio Unidos (Felipe Castillo) - out of race
............Todos por el Peru (Julio Guzman) - barred
............Union for Peru ..Action Popular (Alfredo Barnechea) Center Left Parties:
..Popular Alliance (Alan Garcia) aka: APRA or PAP -  Frente Amplio ("Broad Left Front" or the Residual of Ollanta Humala' 2011 Winning "Gana Peru" coalition).
